questions.text: A patient presence with PUO. He is suspected of suffering from brucellosis. Multiple dilutions of his serum sample are put up for standard agglutination test. The results come as follows- negative agglutination for the serum dilutions 1:20 and 1:50, 1: 0 and 1:160 were positive for agglutination. Which of the following is responsible for the negative test in the first two dilutions?
questions.solution:
Choice D: Antibody excess (Correct Answer)

  • The Standard Agglutination Test (SAT) for Brucellosis follows the prozone phenomenon, where high antibody concentrations can inhibit visible agglutination.
  • In the lower dilutions (1:20, 1:50), antibody concentration is too high, leading to inhibition of agglutination.
  • At higher dilutions (1:80, 1:160), the antibody concentration is optimal, allowing proper antigen-antibody interaction and visible agglutination.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Incomplete antibodies (Incorrect)
    • Incomplete antibodies (blocking antibodies) are seen in Coombs test but are not the cause of false negatives in Brucellosis SAT.
  • Choice B: Incorrect antigen (Incorrect)
    • If the wrong antigen was used, all dilutions would be negative, which is not the case here.
  • Choice C: Antigen excess (Incorrect)
    • Antigen excess causes the postzone phenomenon, which is uncommon in SAT testing. Here, the issue is antibody excess (prozone effect) at lower dilutions.

Key Takeaway

  • Prozone phenomenon occurs due to excess antibodies inhibiting agglutination in lower dilutions.
  • Higher dilutions (1:80, 1:160) balance antigen-antibody interaction, allowing positive agglutination.

questions.text: Cross section of the cell wall of a bacterium is shown. Which is the likely bacterium?
questions.solution:
Choice B: Neisseria meningitidis (Correct Answer)

  • The cross-section of the bacterial cell wall suggests a Gram-negative
  • Neisseria meningitidis is a Gram-negative diplococcus with the following features:
    • Outer membrane containing lipopolysaccharides (LPS)
    • Thin peptidoglycan layer
    • Periplasmic space
    • Capsule (in pathogenic strains)

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Staphylococcus aureus (Incorrect)
    • S. aureus is Gram-positive, which means it lacks an outer membrane and has a thick peptidoglycan layer, unlike what is seen in the image.
  • Choice C: E. coli (Incorrect)
    • While E. coli is Gram-negative, it does not have a characteristic capsule like N. meningitidis, which plays a key role in meningococcal virulence.
  • Choice D: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Incorrect)
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is Gram-negative, but it has a thicker peptidoglycan layer than Neisseria and a more complex outer membrane structure due to its unique porins and efflux pumps.

Key Takeaway

Neisseria meningitidis is a Gram-negative diplococcus with a thin peptidoglycan layer, outer membrane, and capsule, making it the most likely answer based on the cell wall structure.

questions.text: An elderly male presented with meningitis, and the CSF sample was subjected to gram staining and microscopy as shown in the image below. Which of the following will be characteristic of this organism?
questions.solution:
Choice A: Motile at 25°C, non-motile at 37°C (Correct Answer)

  • The Gram stain image is suggestive of Listeria monocytogenes, a Gram-positive bacillus that causes meningitis in elderly and immunocompromised patients.
  • Listeria monocytogenes exhibits "tumbling motility" at 25°C due to the presence of peritrichous flagella.
  • At 37°C, it becomes non-motile as flagella expression is downregulated at body temperature.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Motile at 37°C, non-motile at 22°C (Incorrect)
    • Listeria is non-motile at 37°C, so this is incorrect.
  • Choice C: Motile at 22°C and 37°C (Incorrect)
    • While Listeria is motile at lower temperatures (22-25°C), it loses motility at 37°C.
  • Choice D: Non-motile at 22°C and 37°C (Incorrect)
    • Listeria is motile at 22-25°C due to flagella, so this option is incorrect.

Key Takeaway

Listeria monocytogenes is motile at 25°C ("tumbling motility") but non-motile at 37°C due to loss of flagellar function.

Reference: https://microbe-canvas.com/Bacteria/gram-positive-rods/cells-straight/facultative-anaerobic-4/catalase-positive-1/camp-reaction-4/listeria-monocytogenes.html

questions.text: An isolate from a cancer patient in the critical care unit is found to be resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides and sensitive to cotrimoxazole, ticarcillin- clavulanic acid. What is the likely microorganism?
questions.solution:
Choice D: Stenotrophomonas maltophilia (Correct Answer)

  • Stenotrophomonas maltophilia is an opportunistic, multidrug-resistant, Gram-negative bacillus frequently associated with immunocompromised and critically ill patients, especially those with cancer.
  • It is intrinsically resistant to carbapenems (e.g., meropenem) and aminoglycosidesdue to the presence of metallo-β-lactamases and efflux pumps.
  • However, it is often sensitive to cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) and ticarcillin-clavulanic acid, which is a key diagnostic clue.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Burkholderia cepacia (Incorrect)
    • Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC) is also a multidrug-resistant Gram-negative bacillus and an important nosocomial pathogen, particularly in cystic fibrosis and immunocompromised patients.
    • However, it is usually resistant to aminoglycosides and polymyxins, but it does not typically retain susceptibility to ticarcillin-clavulanic acid.
  • Choice B: Acinetobacter baumannii (Incorrect)
    • Acinetobacter baumannii is a major nosocomial pathogen with high levels of carbapenem resistance, often seen in ICU and ventilator-associated pneumonia cases.
    • However, it is usually resistant to cotrimoxazole and ticarcillin-clavulanic acid, making this an incorrect answer.
  • Choice C: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Incorrect)
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is another multidrug-resistant hospital-acquired pathogen, but it typically retains susceptibility to aminoglycosides (except in rare pan-resistant strains).
    • Additionally, Pseudomonas is usually resistant to cotrimoxazole, unlike Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, which is intrinsically sensitive to it.

Key Takeaway

Stenotrophomonas maltophilia is a nosocomial pathogen that is resistant to carbapenems and aminoglycosides but remains susceptible to cotrimoxazole and ticarcillin-clavulanic acid.

questions.text: Which organism is being transmitted by the vector shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Choice A: Orientia tsutsugamushi (Correct Answer)

  • Orientia tsutsugamushi is the causative agent of Scrub Typhus, a rickettsial disease transmitted by the larval stage (chiggers) of trombiculid mites.
  • The vector in the image is most likely a trombiculid mite, which is characteristic of Scrub Typhus transmission.
  • Scrub typhus is endemic in Asia-Pacific regions and presents with fever, eschar, rash, lymphadenopathy, and multi-organ involvement.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: KFD (Kyasanur Forest Disease) (Incorrect)
    • KFD is a viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Kyasanur Forest Disease Virus (KFDV), which belongs to the Flavivirus family.
    • It is transmitted by hard ticks (Haemaphysalis spinigera), not trombiculid mites.
    • KFD is mainly seen in forested regions of South India.
  • Choice C: Chandipura virus (Incorrect)
    • Chandipura virus is an arbovirus from the Rhabdoviridae family and causes acute encephalitis.
    • It is transmitted by sandflies (Phlebotomus species), not mites.
    • Chandipura virus outbreaks have been reported in India.
  • Choice D: Anaplasma (Incorrect)
    • Anaplasma spp. cause anaplasmosis, a tick-borne disease.
    • It is transmitted by Ixodes ticks, not trombiculid mites.
    • Anaplasmosis mainly affects cattle and humans, causing febrile illness and leukopenia.

Key Takeaway

Orientia tsutsugamushi (Scrub Typhus) is transmitted by chigger mites (larval trombiculid mites), making it the correct answer based on the vector shown in the image.

Reference: https://microbiologyinfo.com/scrub-typhus-etiology-epidemiology-symptoms-pathogenesis-diagnosis-and-treatment/

questions.text: A pregnant female comes for an antenatal checkup. She gives a history of stillbirth at 28 weeks gestation a year ago. She also gives a history of having multiple sexual partners and vaguely remembers having a painless ulcer on the vulva sometime before her last pregnancy. What would be your first step of investigation in this lady?
questions.solution:
Choice A: VDRL (Correct Answer)

  • The patient's history suggests syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum.
  • Key clinical clues:
    • Painless ulcer on the vulva (chancre)→ Suggests primary syphilis in the past.
    • History of stillbirth at 28 weeks→ Strongly suggests congenital syphilis, which is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriages, stillbirths, and neonatal complications.
    • Multiple sexual partners→ Increases risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
  • First-line test: VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory test)
    • VDRL is a non-treponemal screening test for syphilis.
    • If positive, confirmation is done by Treponema pallidum Hemagglutination Assay (TPHA) or Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption Test (FTA-ABS).
    • Early detection and penicillin treatment can prevent complications in future pregnancies.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: HIV ELISA (Incorrect)
    • Given her history of multiple partners, HIV testing is important. However, the first step in this case should be VDRL because her symptoms strongly suggest syphilis.
    • HIV and syphilis co-infection is common, so HIV ELISA should still be performed later.
  • Choice C: Microscopy of ulcer scrape (Incorrect)
    • Dark-field microscopy is used for active syphilitic ulcers to detect Treponema pallidum.
    • However, her ulcer has already healed, making this test irrelevant.
  • Choice D: Culture (Incorrect)
    • Treponema pallidum cannot be cultured in vitro, so this is not a useful diagnostic test.

Key Takeaway

  • VDRL is the first-line test for suspected syphilis in pregnancy, especially with a history of painless genital ulcer and stillbirth.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent congenital syphilis and pregnancy complications.

questions.text: A patient presented with a lesion on the left buttock. He has a history of heart transplant 15 years back. Aspirate from the lesion shows gram-positive branching filamentous bacteria. Identify the organism
questions.solution:
Choice A: Nocardia

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching, filamentous bacterium that is partially acid-fast.
  • It is an opportunistic pathogen, often affecting immunocompromised patients, such as those on immunosuppressive therapy post-organ transplant.
  • Causes cutaneous nocardiosis when introduced via direct inoculation, leading to skin lesions and abscesses.
  • Can also cause pulmonary and disseminated infections.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Mycobacterium tuberculosis
    • TB presents with granulomas and caseating necrosis rather than branching filamentous bacteria.
    • It is acid-fast but does not show filamentous branchinglike Nocardia.
  • Choice C: Bacillus anthracis
    • Bacillus anthracis is a gram-positive rod, but it does not show filamentous branching.
    • Causes cutaneous anthrax, presenting as a painless black eschar, which is not the case here.
  • Choice D: Actinomyces
    • Actinomyces is gram-positive and filamentous, but it is not acid-fast.
    • Typically associated with cervicofacial actinomycosis with sulfur granules, which is not seen in this patient.

Key Takeaway

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching, filamentous, and partially acid-fast bacterium.
  • Commonly affects immunocompromised patients, causing cutaneous, pulmonary, or disseminated infections.
  • Differentiated from Actinomyces by its partial acid-fast staining and from Bacillus anthracis & Mycobacterium tuberculosis by morphology and clinical presentation.

questions.text: Protozoan parasite seen in kupffer cells is?
questions.solution:
Choice D: Leishmania donovani

  • Leishmania donovani is the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar).
  • The parasite exists as amastigotes(intracellular, non-flagellated form) inside Kupffer cells (macrophages of the liver).
  • It primarily affects the liver, spleen, and bone marrow, leading to hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, and fever.
  • Amastigotes are seen inside macrophages/Kupffer cells in Giemsa-stained smears from infected tissues.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Toxoplasma

  • Toxoplasma gondii primarily infects monocytes/macrophages, not Kupffer cells specifically.
  • It is associated with toxoplasmosis, which can cause brain abscesses in immunocompromised patients.

Choice B: Babesia

  • Babesia species infect red blood cells (RBCs), not Kupffer cells.
  • Causes Babesiosis, a malaria-like illness transmitted by Ixodes ticks.

Choice C: Plasmodium vivax

  • Plasmodium species, including P. vivax, infect RBCs and undergo schizogony in hepatocytes, but they do not reside in Kupffer cells.
  • The liver stage (hypnozoites in P. vivaxand P. ovale) is found in hepatocytes, not Kupffer cells.

Key Takeaway:

Leishmania donovani (choice D) is the only protozoan parasite that resides in Kupffer cells, making it the correct answer.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with fever and severe pain in upper right abdominal quadrant. He gives a history of bloody diarrhea 3 weeks back. Abdominal CT shows a lesion in the right lobe of liver, with ragged edges, with multiple septations and heterogeneous densities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Choice C: Amoebic liver abscess

  • Caused by Entamoeba histolytica, which is transmitted via the fecal-oral route.
  • Common in individuals with a history of travel to endemic areas or poor sanitation.
  • History of bloody diarrhea suggests invasive intestinal infection preceding liver involvement.
  • Liver abscess features:
    • More common in the right lobe due to direct portal venous drainage.
    • CT findings: Single or multiple hypodense lesions with irregular margins; may have septations but typically lacks significant internal debris.
    • Anchovy paste aspirate: A key diagnostic feature.
  • Clinical features: Fever, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, and elevated alkaline phosphatase.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Hydatid cyst

  • Caused by Echinococcus granulosus, typically from exposure to dogs/sheep.
  • Presents as a well-defined, cystic lesion with daughter cysts(water lily sign), unlike the described ragged, heterogeneous abscess.
  • No history of preceding diarrhea.

Choice B: Pyogenic liver abscess

  • Caused by bacterial infections (e.g., Klebsiella pneumoniae, coli).
  • Typically seen in diabetics, immunocompromised patients, or following biliary tract infections.
  • Imaging: More likely to show thick-walled, rim-enhancing lesions with significant internal debris.

Choice D: Tuberculous liver abscess (New Option)

  • Rare but possible in endemic TB areas.
  • Usually associated with miliary tuberculosis or immunosuppression.
  • CT findings: May show multiple small granulomas or caseating abscesses, but typically lacks a history of acute bloody diarrhea.

Key Takeaway

The most likely diagnosis is Amoebic liver abscess due to the history of bloody diarrhea followed by a hepatic lesion with typical imaging features.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female from South India comes with complaints of blood, tinged nasal discharge and sometimes epistaxis. The examination revealed pink colored exophytic mass from the right nostril. The patient's image and histopathology are given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Choice B: Rhinosporidiosis

  • Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, an aquatic protozoan-like organism.
  • Epidemiology: Common in South India and Sri Lanka, associated with exposure to stagnant water (e.g., ponds, lakes).
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Pink, polypoidal, exophytic mass in the nasal cavity.
    • Recurrent epistaxis and blood-tinged nasal discharge.
    • Can also affect the conjunctiva, oropharynx, and genital mucosa.
  • Histopathology:
    • Large, thick-walled sporangia containing multiple endospores.
    • Chronic granulomatous inflammation with mixed inflammatory infiltrate.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical excision(wide local excision preferred).
    • Dapsone may help reduce recurrence.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Rhinoscleroma

  • Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (chronic granulomatous bacterial infection).
  • Presentation: Progressive nasal obstruction, crusting, and nodular masses (not typically exophytic pink polyp).
  • Histology: Mikulicz cells(foamy macrophages) with Gram-negative bacilli.

Choice C: Mucormycosis

  • Caused by Mucorales fungi (e.g., Rhizopus, Mucor).
  • Risk Factors: Seen in diabetics, immunocompromised, or post-COVID-19.
  • Presentation: Rapidly progressive, necrotic black eschar in nasal or sinus region (not pink).
  • Histology: Broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching.

Choice D: Lupus vulgaris

  • Cutaneous tuberculosis form caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Presentation: Chronic reddish-brown plaque with apple-jelly nodules on diascopy (not a polypoidal nasal mass).
  • Histology: Caseating granulomas with Langhans giant cells.

Key Takeaway

The most likely diagnosis is Rhinosporidiosis, given the pink, exophytic mass, recurrent epistaxis, and endemicity in South India.

Reference: https://specialist-ent.com/nose-rhinosporidiosis/

questions.text: A 60-year-old male had an injury on the left hand following which his left limb turned erythematous and swollen. He has a history of renal transplant 10 years back. Masson's fontana stain was positive on the biopsy taken from his left limb. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Choice D: Bipolaris spicifera

  • Bipolaris is a dematiaceous (black) fungus, meaning it contains melanin, which stains positive with Masson-Fontana stain.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Immunocompromised states(e.g., post-renal transplant, long-term immunosuppression).
    • Trauma-related inoculation, as seen in this patient with a left-hand injury.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Subcutaneous phaeohyphomycosis: Localized erythematous, swollen lesion at the site of trauma.
    • Can progress to necrosis or deep soft tissue involvement in immunosuppressed individuals.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Histopathology: Pigmented fungal elements in tissues.
    • Masson-Fontana stain: Detects melanin in fungal cell walls (key feature of dematiaceous fungi).
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical excision if localized.
    • Itraconazole or Amphotericin B in severe cases.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Aspergillus fumigatus

  • Common in invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, not post-traumatic subcutaneous infection.
  • Septate hyphae with acute-angle branching(not pigmented fungi).
  • Masson-Fontana stain negative(lacks melanin).

Choice B: Talaromyces marneffei

  • Endemic to Southeast Asia, causes systemic infection in HIV/AIDS
  • Presentation: Fever, pulmonary symptoms, and skin lesions (umbilicated papules).
  • Histology: Shows yeast-like cells with transverse septation inside macrophages.
  • Masson-Fontana stain negative.

Choice C: Blastomyces dermatitidis

  • Causes blastomycosis, commonly seen in North America (Mississippi/Ohio River Valleys).
  • Presentation: Lung involvement, verrucous skin lesions, and osteomyelitis (not localized post-traumatic infection).
  • Histology: Broad-based budding yeasts.
  • Masson-Fontana stain negative.

Key Takeaway

The most likely causative agent is Bipolaris spicifera, a melanin-containing dematiaceous fungus causing post-traumatic phaeohyphomycosis in immunosuppressed individuals.

questions.text: Identify the fungus seen on histology
questions.solution:
Choice A: Mucor

  • Mucorales fungi(e.g., Mucor, Rhizopus, Lichtheimia) cause mucormycosis, an aggressive fungal infection seen in diabetics, immunocompromised patients, and post-COVID-19 cases.
  • Histological Features(Key diagnostic clues):
    • Broad, non-septate hyphae with irregular, right-angle branching (90°).
    • Angioinvasion: Leads to tissue necrosis, infarction, and black eschar formation.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Rhinocerebral mucormycosis: Common in diabetics (DKA), involving the sinuses, orbit, and brain.
    • Pulmonary mucormycosis: Seen in neutropenic patients, causing rapidly progressing pneumonia.
    • Cutaneous mucormycosis: Occurs after traumaor burns.
  • Treatment:
    • Amphotericin B is the drug of choice.
    • Surgical debridement is often necessary.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: Conidiobolus

  • Causes subcutaneous zygomycosis(not angioinvasive like Mucor).
  • Histology: Shows thin-walled, septate hyphae with eosinophilic infiltrates(not broad, non-septate hyphae).
  • Common in tropical regions.

Choice C: Basidiobolus

  • Causes subcutaneous fungal infection, often in children.
  • Histology: Features granulomatous inflammation with eosinophilic material (Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon).
  • Does not invade blood vessels like Mucor.

Choice D: Aspergillus

  • Causes invasive aspergillosis, especially in neutropenic patients.
  • Histology: Shows thin, septate hyphae with acute-angle branching (45°)(contrast with Mucor, which has broad, non-septate hyphae).
  • No right-angle branchingor extensive tissue necrosis like Mucor.

Key Takeaway

The most likely diagnosis is Mucor, characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, which distinguishes it from Aspergillus and other fungi.

Reference: https://dermnetnz.org/topics/mucormycosis-pathology

choices.text: Information is not enough to make a diagnosis

questions.text: An elderly diabetic male on immunosuppressive therapy for kidney transplant 10 years ago, presents with cough and dyspnea for one week. Sputum microscopy shows gram-positive budding yeasts and pseudohyphae. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Choice A: Invasive Candidiasis

  • Caused by Candida species (most commonly Candida albicans).
  • Risk Factors:
    • Diabetes mellitus(impaired immunity).
    • Immunosuppressive therapy post-kidney transplant(increased fungal susceptibility).
  • Key Diagnostic Feature:
    • Gram-positive budding yeasts with pseudohyphae in sputum microscopy→ Suggests Candida, as it forms both yeasts and pseudohyphae in tissues.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Pulmonary candidiasis is rare but occurs in immunocompromised patients with hematogenous spread or aspiration.
    • Symptoms: Cough, dyspnea, fever, and respiratory distress.
    • Diagnosis: Sputum culture, blood culture (for disseminated candidiasis), and imaging.
  • Treatment:
    • Echinocandins (e.g., caspofungin) for severe infections.
    • Fluconazole for mild cases.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: Invasive Aspergillosis

  • Caused by Aspergillus species, typically affects neutropenic or transplant patients.
  • Histology: Thin, septate hyphae with acute-angle branching (45°)(not yeasts with pseudohyphae).
  • Sputum microscopywould show hyphal elements, not budding yeasts.

Choice C: Invasive Mucormycosis

  • Caused by Mucorales fungi (e.g., Rhizopus).
  • Histology: Broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching(not budding yeasts or pseudohyphae).
  • More commonly involves sinuses and brain(rhinocerebral mucormycosis).

Choice D: Information is not enough to make a diagnosis

  • The presence of Gram-positive budding yeasts and pseudohyphae in a transplant patient strongly suggests invasive candidiasis.
  • Additional tests (e.g., culture, β-D-glucan assay) confirm the diagnosis, but the given findings are highly suggestive.

Key Takeaway

The most likely diagnosis is Invasive Candidiasis, given the Gram-positive budding yeasts and pseudohyphae in an immunosuppressed diabetic transplant patient.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a slapped cheek rash and a lacy rash on his trunk and extremities. He had a mild fever a few days prior. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Choice D: Parvovirus B19

  • Causeserythema infectiosum (Fifth disease), a common childhood exanthem.
  • Key Clinical Features:
    • Slapped cheek rash (bright red rash on the cheeks).
    • Lacy, reticular rash on the trunk and extremities.
    • Mild fever and flu-like symptoms precede the rash by a few days.
    • Rash worsens with heat or sunlight.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Infects erythroid progenitor cells, leading to transient anemia.
    • Can cause aplastic crisis in sickle cell disease or hereditary spherocytosis.
    • Associated with hydrops fetalis if transmitted to a fetus.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Human Herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6)

  • Causes Roseola infantum (Sixth disease), primarily in infants (6 months - 2 years).
  • Key Features:
    • High fever for 3-5 days, followed by sudden rash when fever subsides.
    • Rash is rose-colored, non-pruritic, and starts on the trunk, then spreads.
    • No slapped cheek rash.

Choice B: Rubella Virus

  • Causes German measles (Rubella).
  • Key Features:
    • Mild pink maculopapular rash starting on the face, spreading downward.
    • Postauricular and occipital lymphadenopathy.
    • No slapped cheek or lacy rash.

Choice C: Measles Virus

  • Causes Rubeola (Measles).
  • Key Features:
    • Prodrome: High fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis.
    • Koplik spots(white lesions on buccal mucosa).
    • Rash: Starts on face and spreads downward, darkens over time.
    • No slapped cheek or lacy rash.

Key Takeaway

The most likely diagnosis is Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth disease) caused by Parvovirus B19, given the slapped cheek appearance and lacy rash following a mild fever.
